critique: This document primarily concerns the internal organization and hierarchy of the US Foreign Service. It outlines supervisory powers, jurisdictional boundaries, and relative ranks within the service. There's little to suggest a strong ideological leaning, as it focuses on administrative structure. Immigration is not addressed. Executive power is somewhat expanded, as the order clarifies and reinforces the authority of diplomatic representatives and consuls general under the Department of State, ultimately overseen by the executive branch. Federalism isn't directly impacted, as the document deals with the internal workings of a federal agency. National security vs. civil liberties is not a salient point here. Economic regulation is not relevant. Social inclusion is not a factor in this document.
